I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the Association of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Secretariat and its Member States1 to implement the ASEAN 
Agreement on Disaster Management and Emergency Response (AADMER) Work Programme 
2021–20252 by  supporting  increased  cooperation  and  enhancing  capacity  on  disaster  risk 
management  (DRM). 3  The  TA  will  contribute  by  (i)  increasing  regional  cooperation  on 
transboundary  risks,  (ii)  introducing  high-level  technology  for  regional  cooperation  on 
transboundary risks, and (iii) advancing interregional cooperation through capacity building and 
knowledge exchange.  
 
2.  The TA is not included in the 2021 ADB Management-approved results-based work plan 
of the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC).4 The TA is consistent 
with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Strategy 2030’s operational priorities 1 (addressing 
remaining poverty and reducing inequalities); 3 (tackling climate change, building climate and 
disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental  sustainability);  and  7  (fostering  regional 
cooperation  and  integration).  It  will  also  strengthen  linkages  with  operational  priority  2  on 
accelerating progress in gender equality.5  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Southeast Asia has some of the world’s most extensive transboundary disaster risks, 
including  droughts  and  floods  in  the  Mekong  Basin;  earthquakes,  tsunamis,  and  volcanic 
eruptions across the Ring of Fire; and tropical cyclones and storms along coastlines and islands. 
With the increasing levels of disaster risk—in part driven by the concentration of people and 
assets in hazard-exposed areas, environmental degradation, and climate change—the region 
needs to strengthen its cooperation and capacity to enhance regional public goods and reduce 
the social and economic impacts from transboundary disasters and emergencies. 
 
4.  Since 2009, ASEAN has led the region’s DRM efforts through the AADMER, a legally 
binding agreement on regional cooperation in disaster management and emergency response.6 
Since coming into force, it has provided a framework for ASEAN in advancing efforts to realize its 
vision of building “a region of disaster-resilient nations, mutually assisting and complementing one 
another, sharing a common bond in minimizing adverse effects of disasters in pursuit of safer 
communities and sustainable development” (footnote 2). The AADMER is operationalized through 
5-year work programs, developed by the ASEAN Committee on Disaster Management. The work 
program provides a platform for coordination among development partners to ensure synergies 
and avoid overlap. 
 
5.  The first AADMER work program (2010–2015) put in place regional mechanisms for joint 
response and disaster risk reduction, including establishing wide-ranging partnerships. The 
second work program (2016–2020) focused on protecting development gains through priority

programs covering risk assessment, disaster prevention and mitigation, disaster preparedness 
and emergency response, disaster recovery, and knowledge and innovation. The third and current 
work program (2021–2025) seeks to enhance and support ASEAN’s disaster risk reduction and 
disaster  management  capabilities  through  five  priority  programs—risk  assessment  and 
monitoring, prevention and mitigation, preparedness and response, resilient recovery, and global 
leadership—each overseen by one of the three ASEAN Committee on Disaster Management 
working groups and co-chaired by the ASEAN Member States. 
 
6.  Recognizing the AADMER’s increasing maturity over successive work programs, the 
scope and ambition of the current work program have expanded to cover slow-onset hazards 
such as drought, and play a more active role in transboundary issues at both the operational and 
normative levels. Further, the work program seeks to engage with regional DRM organizations 
outside ASEAN to exchange knowledge and build mutually beneficial working relationships.7 
 
7.  While the AADMER was developed before the adoption of the Sendai Framework for 
Disaster Risk Reduction8 and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs),9 the subsequent work 
programs responded to the commitments made by ASEAN Member States on resilient and 
sustainable development, particularly SDGs 1, 5, 11, and 13.10 The current work program has 
clear synergies with ADB’s Strategy 2030, as both seek to scale up support to address disaster 
risks, climate change, and environmental degradation; take a comprehensive approach to building 
climate and disaster resilience; and increase support for regional public goods and collective 
actions to mitigate cross-border risks. 
 
8.  In 2017, the Integrated Disaster Risk Management (IDRM) Fund—an ADB-administered 
trust fund established in 2013 with financing support from the Government of Canada, which 
aimed to help develop innovative regional solutions to DRM in Southeast Asia developing member 
countries (DMCs)—provided assistance to the second work program (2016–2020).11 The IDRM 
Fund supported five of the eight priority areas of the second work program, including initiatives 
such as the Build Safely program and the ASEAN Recovery Forum, as well as the development 
of ASEAN guidelines on risk and vulnerability assessment, social protection in disaster recovery, 
and urban resilience. The IDRM Fund also provided capacity building to the ASEAN Secretariat. 
Despite high aspirations, the ASEAN Secretariat and member DMCs still have organizational and 
capacity constraints. The implementation of activities in DMCs and the capacity of the ASEAN 
Secretariat both require investment to deliver the work program in support of the regional public 
good of advancing regional cooperation in DRM.12 The coronavirus disease (COVID-19) has 
highlighted further opportunities to leverage digital solutions for enhancing cooperation. Closing 
the regional digital divide will require greater investment in digital readiness, including putting in 
place  data  and  knowledge  sharing  protocols,  storing  mechanisms,  and  user-friendly  and 
accessible applications, among others.13 The sustainability of this TA is premised on supporting 
agreed approaches within ASEAN by fostering an enabling environment for further investment in 
DMCs.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  ASEAN  Member  States’  resilience  to 
transboundary risks improved.14 The TA will have the following outcome: ASEAN’s transboundary 
DRM capabilities enhanced.15 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Regional cooperation on understanding transboundary risks increased. 
Based on a comprehensive analysis, and in recognition of the transboundary nature of disaster 
risk and the benefits of regional cooperation in reducing and managing disaster risk, the TA will 
support gender and socially inclusive as well as context-sensitive disaster scenario planning, risk 
assessments, and risk profiling using an ASEAN-agreed approach. This output is expected to 
increase actionable knowledge and greater understanding between DMCs on the transboundary 
implications of disasters and enhance evidence-based decision-making. This will include regional 
or multicountry scenario planning and risk assessments on key transboundary hazards, such as 
flood,  drought,  tsunami,  tropical  cyclone,  and  heat  wave  events,  as  well  as  increasing 
understanding on different climate change scenarios on hazards using, preferably, an open-
source geographic information system. The results of the output are expected to feed into relevant 
ASEAN processes and programs, and inform investment projects within DMCs.  
 
11.  To support greater engagement of women as leaders in community-based DRM as well 
as  action  on  disaster-responsive  social  protection,16 the  TA  will  enhance  the  capacity  of 
grassroots women-led organizations across ASEAN. Drawing on good practice from the IDRM 
Fund (footnote 12, where grassroots women’s organizations proved effective in spearheading 
community-based DRM, the support will facilitate leadership development, strengthen knowledge, 
and  harness  peer-to-peer  learning  and  networking  across  the  region,  including  in  tackling 
transboundary hazards.  
 
12.  To advance the implementation of the ASEAN Declaration on the Strengthening of 
Adaptation to Drought,17 selected DMCs will be supported to implement gender and socially 
inclusive action to prepare for and reduce drought risk. 
 
13.  Output 2: High-level technology for regional cooperation on transboundary risks 
introduced. The AADMER Work Programme 2021–2025 builds on the ASEAN Information and 
Communication Technology (ICT) Roadmap on Disaster Management, which provides several 
entry points for the integration of high-level technology and innovative solutions to improve ICT 
efficiency, productivity, quality, functionality, and access.18 A key priority of the AADMER Work 
Programme is the development of an online platform (or an innovation hub) that will serve as the 
ASEAN-wide repository of knowledge products and tools on risk assessment, disaster risk 
reduction, preparedness, response, recovery, and training programs; support data visualizations 
and geographic information system applications; capture innovative DRM solutions and learning 
among ASEAN Member States; and provide a platform for a virtual network and community of 
peers. The TA will support a user-centered design process and understanding of the ecosystem,

which includes (i) the ASEAN Resilient Recovery Toolbox, a repository of knowledge products on 
best practices, training manuals, and guidelines on recovery; and (ii) the ASEAN Disaster 
Information Network, a repository of information on hazards and disasters that have occurred in 
the region.  
 
14.  The TA will support the development of guidelines for the online platform, including 
standards,  protocols,  regulations,  and  safeguards  on  the  use  of  digital  technology  for 
transboundary  risks.  Priority  digital  solutions  that  will  be  explored  include  monitoring  and 
predictive analysis for slow-onset hazards, social media monitoring and analysis for early warning, 
artificial intelligence for cloud computing, and data mining on post-disaster recovery. The TA will 
support the development of a data governance strategy that addresses interoperability, privacy, 
and security. The TA will support the application of selected digital solutions for disaster risk 
reduction and post-disaster recovery in two ASEAN DMCs.  
 
15.  Output  3:  Interregional  cooperation  through  capacity  building  and  knowledge 
exchange  advanced.  Leveraging  ASEAN’s  leadership  in  DRM,  the  TA  will  support  the 
establishment of a dialogue mechanism between ASEAN and selected peer regional bodies to 
enhance collaboration and knowledge exchange on DRM. Positioned at the technical level, a 
governance structure and work plan will be developed to guide efforts to increase collaboration 
and knowledge exchange and to identify opportunities for capacity building. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.3 million, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund,19 (ii) $500,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by the High-Level Technology Fund,20 and (iii) $300,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Government of Canada, all to be administered by ADB. 
 
17.  Ineligible items under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund include civil works, 
the procurement of large-scale equipment (such as machinery and other capital equipment), and 
salaries for permanent staff of the TA’s executing and/or implementing agencies. Expenditures 
related to technologies that are undergoing early-stage research and development are ineligible 
under the High-Level Technology Fund. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will administer the TA. The Climate Change and Disaster Risk Management Division 
of  ADB’s  SDCC  will  implement  the  TA  in  close  coordination  with  ADB’s  Southeast  Asia 
Department and the ASEAN Secretariat. ADB will leverage the AADMER’s coordination function 
to ensure synergies and avoid overlap with other development partners. ADB’s SDCC will select, 
supervise, and evaluate consultants; organize workshops; and provide staff to act as resource 
persons in workshops.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the High-Level Technology Fund, 
(ii) ADB administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 
to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of Canada, and (iii) ADB providing the balance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for Strengthening Cooperation on 
Disaster Risk Management within the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.
